headline: A New Thriller Is Coy About Its Director. (It’s Mel Gibson.)
summary: For “Flight Risk,” his first outing as a director in nearly a decade, the Oscar winner isn’t quite taking center stage.

headline: Prince’s ‘Purple Rain’ Takes the Stage in Minneapolis
summary: There was a flourish of purple at the State Theater for the debut of a new musical adaptation of the performer’s 1984 movie in his hometown in Minnesota.

headline: The Great Gritty New York Movie You’ve Never Seen
summary: The crime thriller “Night of the Juggler” has been restored for a new theatrical release. It captures 1970s New York history and includes great chase scenes along the way.

headline: ‘Star Trek: Section 31’ Review: Set the Phasers to Shun
summary: This made-for-streaming Star Trek adventure starring Michelle Yeoh is an exhausting gallop of nonstop chatter and nonhuman abilities.

headline: When Watching These Films at Cannes, Feel Free to Put Your Feet in the Sand
summary: Cinéma de la Plage is the Cannes Film Festival’s free program of nightly film screenings on the beach and under the stars.

headline: ‘When Fall Is Coming’ Review: Cooking Up a Mystery
summary: With her kind eyes and guileless smile, Hélène Vincent plays a sweet old French lady. But looks can be deceiving in this François Ozon film.

headline: In Death, Poet Andrea Gibson Gets a Film That Celebrates Life
summary: “Come See Me in the Good Light” follows the writer and their wife as they experienced the pain of cancer and also the joy of living.

headline: ‘Warfare’ Review: A Combat Movie That Refuses to Entertain
summary: In Alex Garland and Ray Mendoza’s film about an American platoon in Iraq, there is no admirably staged bloodshed or witty repartee. That’s the point.

headline: Nine Inch Nails Are Filling the Hole in Their Souls With Film Music
summary: Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross’s soundtrack for “Tron: Ares” is their first under their acclaimed band’s name. These days, the project “feels vital and exciting again.”

headline: ‘Parthenope’ Review: Goddess Worship
summary: Directed by Paolo Sorrentino, this decadent drama about a beautiful young woman is a one-sided meditation on art, desire and spirituality.

headline: ‘Mr. Scorsese’ Review: A Captivating and Charismatic Profile
summary: Rebecca Miller’s five-part documentary series balances her esteem for the director with a clear eye toward his struggles.

summary: This made-for-streaming Star Trek adventure starring Michelle Yeoh is an exhausting gallop of nonstop chatter and nonhuman abilities.

headline: ‘Rule Breakers’ Review: Afghanistan’s First Robotics Team
summary: Based on a true story, this wholesome movie centers on four girls who make it to a worldwide competition in Washington, despite the odds.

summary: The thriller series premieres on Prime Video, and the 77th annual Emmy Awards air on Sunday.

headline: Jack Black Hits the Charts With Another Song From a Video Game Movie
summary: “Steve’s Lava Chicken,” a 34-second song from “A Minecraft Movie,” made the Billboard Hot 100. He charted before with a song from “The Super Mario Bros. Movie.”

headline: Gene Hackman: 13 Memorable Movies to Stream
summary: He played a complicated hero in “The French Connection” and an arch-villain in “Superman.” Here are some of Hackman’s career highlights.

headline: How Did ‘Hercules’ Get So Lame?
summary: A Disney musical based on the 1997 animated movie feels as though its creators wanted to get to the finish line and move on.

headline: Last Year’s Cannes Winners Won Big at Oscars. Can the 2025 Crop Do the Same?

headline: Amie Donald Has the Moves as the Killer Robot in ‘M3gan 2.0’
summary: The sunny 15-year-old dancer-turned-actress is about as far as you can get from the role she’s best known for: a deadly A.I. doll.

summary: The sequel to the deranged 2018 comedy finds Blake Lively and Anna Kendrick feuding in the Italian sun.

headline: ‘Riff Raff’ Review: These Jokes Don’t Kill
summary: The dark mayhem spun up by this crime comedy might seem a little familiar.

headline: ‘The Damned’ Review: Unfortunate Sons
summary: In Roberto Minervini’s intimate and impressionistic drama, a group of Civil War scouts faces the harsh realities of the uncharted Montana territory.

headline: A New Requirement for Oscar Voters: They Must Actually Watch the Films
summary: The new rule, announced this week by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, was greeted with laughter and disbelief that it had not been required all along.

headline: The Strangely Beautiful Realities You Can Discover in a Ken Jacobs Film
summary: The avant-garde director, who died Sunday, changed our ideas of what cinema was and could be while showing us the old, lost New York.

headline: ‘Springsteen: Deliver Me From Nowhere’: What’s Fact, What’s Fictionalized

headline: Theater to Stream: Morgan Freeman in ‘Gospel at Colonus’ and More

summary: Finally getting a theatrical run, Zeinabu irene Davis’s 1999 film about two Black couples in Chicago in two different eras earns its landmark status.

summary: The writer and director of “The Invisible Man,” 21st-century style, is back with an interpretation of another Universal Pictures monster movie, “Wolf Man.”

headline: Three Great Documentaries to Stream
summary: In this month’s picks, a chilling true-crime entry, a movie about an execution equipment manufacturer and a devilish doc from the “Exorcist” director William Friedkin.

headline: When Coming to America, European Directors Sometimes Get Lost in Translation
summary: The history of European directors “going Hollywood” and making the leap to English-language filmmaking is long and uneven.

headline: 21 Movies, Books and Albums With a Theater Focus to Consume During the Holidays
summary: Make it through the holidays with these movies, books and music from the past year that are adapted from stage productions or evoke a theatrical spirit.

headline: Guy Pearce Never Needed to Be a Movie Star
summary: After roles in “Memento” and “L.A. Confidential” made him famous, Pearce turned his back on Hollywood. At age 57, he’s returned in “The Brutalist.”

headline: Julia Roberts and Luca Guadagnino on ‘After the Hunt’ and Daring to Be Ambiguous
summary: The film touches on #MeToo and cancel culture, but the star and director wanted audiences to make up their own minds.
